As has been true in radio, it will be necessary to make feasibility
studies' .and surveys in connection with proposed television facilities0 These
studies should be made by a team including a competent electronics engineer
familiar with television problems, and a person having managerial and pro¬
gramming experience in the educational uses of television0 After consultation
with USOM personnel and the appropriate host country officials, such a team
woiiLd be able to draft a total plan for a television installation and an
organization designed to achieve maximum use of the facility® ICA should
indicate a willingness to consider requests for feasibility studies and surveys
looking toward the installation of television facilities®
Of particular interest to ICA should be the development of closed
circuit, or low power open circuit, television installations in institutions
of learning® Such installations are relatively inexpensive and offer the
most feasible and practical means available for the multiplication in use
of available educational resources® Installations of this type have proven
to be highly successful in the United States, and their number is increasing
substantially each year® It is recommended therefore, that ICA consider the
establishment of several pilot television installations in key areas of the
world, with the view of improving and expanding the educational program of
specific institutions® As these projects develop and mature they can serve
as illustrative models for other countries within the area® ICA would then
be in a position to entertain requests for the development of such facilities
on a wide scale®
As regular broadcasting television stations come on the air in
various countries, with or without ICA assistance, opportunity will arise
for the development of program agencies capable of using a portion of station
time for educational purposes® ICA should give favorable consideration to
requests for help in establishing such agencies in all countries where stations
exist or are about to come into being® Normally, assistance of this type
could be expected to take the form of providing a qualified educational
television advisor who would help the host country organize such an agency
and provide guidance in its programming efforts®
A necessary aspect of ICA?s television policy must be the willingness
to provide training for managerial, programming, and engineering personnel®
Such training might include participant training in the United States, and
on-the-job training at the local installation® ICA should favorably consider
requests for the training of television personnel®
The major technical obstacle in the way of widespread use of television
in the underdeveloped parts of the world is the availability and distribution
of receivers® This constitutes a problem that must be attacked with vigor®
ICA should encourage in every way possible the development of inexpensive,
simplified television receivers® It is further suggested that through the
Office of Industrial Resources, ICA undertake to explore the establishment
of receiver assembly plants when so requested, and that such plants be imple¬
mented wherever they are feasible and practical.
